awd_titl_txt: HCC: Small: Collaborative Research:  Asynchrony and Persistence for Complex Contact Stimulations
awd_abstract_narration:
IIS - 0916129   
HCC: Small: Collaborative Research: Asynchrony and Persistence for Complex Contact Simulations
Grinspun, Eitan           
Columbia University

Collaborative Proposals
IIS - 0914833           
Guibas, Leonidas J      
Stanford University

ABSTRACT
This proposal addresses the challenge of complex contact simulations by working entirely in an asynchronous setting. The project operates along three lines, combining tools from Asynchronous Variational Integrators (AVIs) and Kinetic Data Structures (KDSs) with a novel effort to perform and exploit qualitative analysis of contact simulation data. The first investigation will show that AVIs, meant to handle the continuous aspects of the physics, can be ntegrated well with KDSs, meant to handle discrete geometric events. The second research component addresses the fundamental problem of event scheduling when future trajectories are uncertain. Methods will be explored that improve event detection times, reduce the number of auxiliary events that have to be processed, and allow events to be processed in parallel.   The third research task will be to initiate a study of the qualitative behavior of contact simulation by building a hierarchy of coarser models which can then be used for better resource allocation, for the validation of various approximations, and in improved simulation design to attain desired effects.

por.por_cntn:
Across science, engineering, and medicine we are constantly in need of better tools that blend the physical and virtual words, allowing better capture and simulation. This project has focused on developing efficient algorithms for computer graphics problems that blend geometry and physics in essential ways, in both virtual and real settings. One such setting is physical simulations with multiple or complex contacts between different bodies, including distributed points of contact, interaction with sharp boundaries, mixtures of resting and sliding, etc. By combining asynchronous variational integrators from computational physics and kinetic data structures from computational geometry, we have been able to derive and demonstrate new algorithms with improved efficiency, safety, and robustness. We have designed coarser physical models that capture essential qualities of an evolving physical system and allow long-term simulations to be performed in a much shorter time.  We successfully demonstrated significant insights into macromolecular folding pathways using such a qualitative dynamics approach based on Markov state models. We have also developed and tested new techniques for the real-time capture of the geometry of indoor environment containing multiple instances of objects that may undergo articulation or deformation (e.g., swivel chairs, cabinets w. drawers). The results of this research have been published in top venues in computer graphics and computational biology. A number of the ideas have led to collaborations with companies in Silicon Valley working on improved shape search and 3D acquisition. The project has also contributed to the training of two postdocs and five graduate students, including two whose Ph.D. thesis largely reflects research topics under this grant.

Modified by: Leonidas J Guibas
